title: 105_hr3613
content: The "Military Health Care Fairness Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes certain covered beneficiaries in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. The "Military Health Care Fairness Act" allows eligible beneficiaries to enroll in any health benefits plan under the Federal Employee Health Benefits program, offering medical care comparable to authorized care. The Secretary of Defense and other administering Secretaries will enter into an agreement with the Director of the Office of Personnel Management to implement this provision. The "Military Health Care Fairness Act" allows eligible beneficiaries, including military retirees and their dependents, to enroll in an FEHBP plan if they do not have guaranteed access to comparable health care benefits under TRICARE or are eligible but not enrolled in TRICARE for various reasons. Eligible beneficiaries, including military retirees 65 years of age or older and those retired under chapter 61, can enroll in an FEHBP plan without needing to meet chapter 89 eligibility criteria. Enrollment priority is based on the order of application. Eligible beneficiaries can apply to enroll in an FEHBP plan for a minimum period of three years. The Secretary maintains a list of applicants unable to enroll due to funding constraints. Enrollment is provided for 90 days before program implementation and annually thereafter. Discontinuing enrollment before the minimum period renders a beneficiary ineligible for reenrollment. Eligible beneficiaries enrolled in an FEHBP plan can receive care at a military medical treatment facility, with the plan reimbursing the facility for the cost of treatment. Adjustments may be made to copayments to ensure no additional costs to the plan. Contributions for enrollment are made as if the beneficiary were a federal employee, with the administering Secretary responsible for government contributions. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management determines Government contributions payable by the Secretary under section 8906 of title 5 for enrolled eligible beneficiaries. Each beneficiary in an FEHBP plan must contribute as a similarly situated Federal employee. The Director manages participation in the Federal Employee Health Benefits program, maintaining separate risk pools for eligible beneficiaries. The Director manages participation in the Federal Employee Health Benefits program, ensuring Government contributions for enrolled eligible beneficiaries. A joint report to Congress by the Secretary of Defense and the Director of the Office of Personnel Management is required annually, detailing healthcare provision to beneficiaries under the program. The annual joint report to Congress by the Secretary of Defense and the Director of the Office of Personnel Management details the utilization and costs of health care services for eligible beneficiaries under the Federal Employee Health Benefits program. The Secretary of Defense will submit a report to Congress four years after the National Defense Authorization Act for fiscal year 1999, evaluating the recommendation for a permanent health care option for retired covered beneficiaries and estimating the associated costs. The Secretary of Defense will report to Congress on a permanent health care option for retired covered beneficiaries and the estimated costs. The Secretary of Defense will report to Congress on a permanent health care option for retired covered beneficiaries and the estimated costs. Section 8905 and 8906 of title 5, United States Code, are amended to allow eligible beneficiaries under section 1079b of title 10 to enroll in a health benefits plan under the Federal Employees Health Benefits program. The amendment allows individuals enrolled in a health plan under section 8905(d) of title 5 to receive Government contributions determined under section 1079b(g) of title 10. The Secretary of Defense must offer health benefits under section 1079b(a) of title 10 within 6 months of the enactment of the Act. The option will be available through 2003, with care provided until 2005. $100 million is authorized for fiscal year 1999 and $200 million for fiscal year 2000. Funding amounts allocated for fiscal years 2000 to 2005 are as follows: $200 million for 2000, $300 million for 2001, $400 million for 2002, $500 million for 2003, and as necessary for 2004 and 2005.
